titleStmt.title: The Parliamentary intelligencer [no.25 (11 June-18 June 1660)] comprising the sum of forraign intelligence with the affairs now in agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland : for information of the people.
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, 1628 or 1629-1692, editor.
Dury, Giles, editor.
Macock, John, publisher.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

notesStmt.note: Edited by Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Imprint varies: No. 1-19 Printed by John Macock; no. 20-53 Printed by John Macock and Tho. Newcomb.
Dates given according to Lady-Day dating.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Numb. 25 (11-18 Jun. 1660) called: Numb. 26; numb. 29 misprinted as "9".

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 26. THE Parliamentary Intelligencer, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence, with the Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order of the late Council of State. From Monday June 11. to Monday June 18. 1660.
From St. John de Luz, June 8. Being a full Account of the Ceremonies of the Marriage.
div.p:
THe ≈øecond in≈øtant the King of Spain came to Fontarabia; the fir≈øt ceremony of the Kings Marriage with the Infanta was performed the next day by the Bi≈øhop of Pampolona, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Patriarch of the India's, in the Church of that Town, the Ceremonies whereof you had in the la≈øt. I ≈øhall add only what particulars of con≈øequence that were then omitted. The Bi≈øhop of Frojus was there to ≈øee the Ceremony, with Two or three hundred French Gentlemen, Madamoi≈øelle was there al≈øo, but incognito, and went for the waiting Gentlewoman of the Lady No ‚Ä¢ illes,
yet the King of Spaines guards had ≈øom ≈øpeciall re≈øpect for her, and kept her from being mole≈øted by the crowd, during the Ma≈øs. Aafter the reading of the King's Proxy to Don Lewis d' Aro, the renunciation made by the Infanta of any preten≈øions to the States of Spain was al≈øo read, which ≈øhe then confirmed by an Oath. The re≈øt of the ceremonyes u≈øed then were not much differing from the ceremony is u≈øed at other mariages, but onely in point of ≈øtateline≈øs. It was ob≈øerved that the Infanta kneeled twice before the King her Father, the fir≈øt time to ask his ble≈ø≈øing, and the ≈øecond afore ≈øhe gave her con≈øent to the mariage. She did ≈øhed teares at fir≈øt, but ≈øoon after ≈øhe appeared very re≈øolute. The King of Spain who ≈øtood covered all the while, took the Ring, as it was agreed the day before, and did put it on his Daughter's finger. The ceremony being ended, the King of Spain ≈øhewed her all the re≈øpect due to ≈øuch a Queen, and gave her the right hand, both at the coming out of the Church, and in his owne Coach. He likewi≈øe gave her his owne lodgings and took hers; and that new Queen, which as yet had not been ≈øeen in publick, dined there publickly in a large room, where Madamoi≈øelle and all the French there ru≈øhed in in a croud. When the ≈øaid Queen had dined, ≈øhe ≈ømiled upon Madamoi≈øelle, and told her ≈øhe very well knew the unknown Lady whom ≈øhe called into her owne chamber, and gave her many te≈øtimonyes of her affections, after which Madamoi≈øelle returned hither with much ≈øatisfaction. About two a clock in the afternoon, the news of that ce ‚Ä¢ emony was brought to the King, who received it with much joy, as did al≈øo the Queen mother, who looks upon that mariage as her owne worke. That night there was a great Ball ‚Ä¢ t our Townhou≈øe, where the King daunced fir≈øt with Madamoi≈øelle; after whom Mon≈øieur the King's Brother took Madamoi≈øelle d' Alencon, and danced with her, the Count d' Armagnac with Madamoi≈øelle de Valois, and other Lords and Grandees with the Prince≈øs of Baden, the Dutche≈øs of Valentinois, and the other Ladyes of the Court, all richly aparelled and adorned with abundance of Jewels. The fourth in≈øtant
the Duke of Crequi, fir≈øt Gentleman of the King's chamber, went with a very great and gallant retinue, and abundance of Nobility accompanying him from hence, to carry the pre≈øents to the new Queen, the particulars whereof you have hereafter; ≈øhe received them with all the demon≈øtrations of joy that can be imagined. The Marquis of Vardos complimented her likewi≈øe in the Kings name as ≈øome daies before the Count de Noailles Captaine of the Kings lifeguard did.

The ≈øame day the Queen mother went to the I≈øle of the Conference, where ≈øhe came about 2 a clock in the afternoon, and ≈øoon after the King of Spain and the Queen his Daughter with her Ladies of honor, came there in a Galliot, covered, painted within and without, being followed with another wherein was Don Lewis De Haro and ≈øeveral Spani≈øh Grandees; after whom came a great number of ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels, very gallant, wherein was the re≈øt of the Spani≈øh Court. The ≈øhore was full of people, who admired the beauty of that Prince≈øs, which was much advantaged by the great quantity of Diamonds that were upon her rich garments. The King of Spain came a≈øhore fir≈øt, and took the Queen his Daughter by the hand, and conducted her to the very doore of the Chamber of the Conference, where the Queen Mother of France, the Kings brother, and the Cardinal Mazarine were: we hear not as yet what was done at that meeting, but they looked all to bevery well ≈øatisfied at their coming out. During their Conference the K: of France was incognito on hor≈øeback, within a musket ≈øhot, between a Riv ‚Ä¢ let and a Hill, with the Prince of Conty; and the Counts of Soi≈ø≈øons and Armagnac, and divers other Grandees of the French Court, intending to cro≈øs the River that is about the I≈øle of the Conference, that he might ≈øee by the by the new Queen at the Window, with the Queen Mother; but the Kings impatience made him change his de≈øign, and he went alone by the doore of the Gallery to the very doore of the Chamber, where he di≈øtinctly ≈øaw the King of Spain and the new Queeen his Spou≈øe. Don Lewis de Haro and the Cardinal Mazarine,
who managed that bu≈øine≈øs, for his Maje≈øties ≈øatisfaction, ≈øtood by the doore the better to conceal him all the while he was there. His Maje≈øty retired after with much ≈øatisfaction, and declared to all that he had found the Queen very hand≈øome.

Not content to have ≈øeen her there, the King went towards the ≈øhore, where he had a full ≈øight of her going again into the Galliot. From thence the Spani≈øh Court returned to Fontarabia, and their Maje≈øties came likewi≈øe hither. The 5 the King ≈øent a Complement to the King and Queen of Spain by Mr. de Ballinghew the fir≈øt Gentleman of the Hor≈øe. The 6 the two Kings met together in Private at the I≈øle of the Conference; and returned again thither the next day, with their whole Courts. During the whole time of their Interview both the Kings were ≈øtill ‚Ä¢ ncovered, that the Grandees of Spain might not have occa≈øion to be covered, and both ≈øwore the Peace, the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King in the hands of the Bi≈øhop of Bayonne, in the pre≈øence of Don Lewis de Haro; and the King of Spain in the hands of the Bi≈øhop of Pampelona, in the pre≈øence of the Cardinal Mazarine, who offered to the ≈øaid King of Spain Mr. de Mancini for an ho≈øtage for the re≈øtitution of Ro≈øes and the other places, but he refu≈øed to take him, ≈øaying, That he would have no other a≈ø≈øurances for it, but the word of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty. Then having delivered his Daughter into the Kings hands, the Queen Mother took her in her Coach, and the two Kings pa ‚Ä¢ ted with all the demon≈øtrations of a perfect amity. The new Queen being come to St. John de Luz, had the whole next day, being the 8 In≈øtant, to wipe off her tears, The ≈øame the Spani≈øh begun their Journey towards Madrid. The King ≈øent the Marquis de Villequier, to complement the King of Spain before his departure. The 9 the la≈øt Ceremony of the Marriage was performed, whereat Cardinal Mazarine di≈øcharged the place of grand Almoner; Madamoi≈øelle carried the Taper; and the two Prince≈ø≈øes of Alencon and Valois her Si≈øters caryed the Queens Train, with the Prince≈øs of Carignan.

At the Enterview where the two Kings ≈øwore the Peace there were only pre≈øent the Royall per≈øons, the two chief Mini≈øters, and the Secretarys of State of both the Crowns. After the taking of the Oath, the two Kings ≈øigned it, and afterwards they imbraced one another. The Guards on both ≈øides gave two Volleys; The French Guards were divided in three Squadrons, the fir≈øt of the Gen≈ødarmes, the ≈øecond the Lifeguard, and the third of the light hor≈øemen, and two foot Bataillons, the fir≈øt of the Kings Musketeers, and the other of the French and Switzer Guards, all in blew Ca≈øacks. The Spaniards were in five Squadrons, and a great Bataillon, all in yeallow Coats, with the Spani≈øh Scutcheon before and behind, and St Andrew's Cro≈ø≈øe upon the ≈øides.

div.head: A particular account of the Pre≈øents the Infanta hath received from the French Court.
div.p: Fir≈øt, a rich Cabinet garni≈øhed with Gold and Diamonds and the Kings Cyphers, and her own with Royal Cowns.

In that Cabinet are ≈øix compleat Suites of Jewels, viz. one all of Diamonds, the Pendants, the Pre≈øtador, the Po≈øy, the Knots for the ≈øleeves, and to put before, behind, and at the ≈øides of the Gown, the ≈ømall Chaine, the picture box, the Watch with the Chaine, and the little Hook, all of Diamonds.
A like ≈øuit all of Pearls.
Another of Pearls and Diamonds mixed together.
Another of Diamonds and Rubies.
Another of Emerauds and Diamonds.

Be≈øides a Watch of the ≈øame, with the Pictures following, viz. of the King and Queen of Spain, of the Prince of Spain, and of the young Infanta, of the King of France, and the two Queens, all garni≈øhed with Diamonds. And a Ring of a great value, the whole being of a va≈øt price, all ≈øent the ≈øaid Infanta by the King. She is be≈øides to have the u≈øe of all the Crown Jewels. which never went out of the Kingdom.
A great Box full of gold and ≈øilver pieces, to make her liberalites.
Another with 80000 ≈ømall gold Lewi≈øes.
Sent to the Infanta by the Queen Mother of France.
A ≈øtring of Pearls worth 100000 Crowns, be≈øides that which the King ≈øent her.
A Bodkin of Diamonds, of a very great price.
Pendants worth 600000 Livres.
And a very fine Box for a Picture.
Sent her by Mon≈øieur the Kings Brother.

A Cabinet garni≈øhed with Gold and Silver together, wherein were twelve Suits of Diamonds, Pearls, Emerauds and Rubeis, Turquoi≈øes, Emerauds & Rubeis together, Jacinths, Amethy≈øts &c. & al in ≈øuch great quantity, that there be enough to lace her gowns, the ≈øtones being ≈øet in the form of a Lace.
Sent her by Cardinal Mazarin.
The worth of 1200000 Livres in Jewels.

A Diamond of an exce≈ø≈øive bigne≈øs and price, which he intreated the Infanta to keep with the Crown Jewels, which are never to go out of France, but for all the re≈øt ≈øhe may di≈øpo≈øe of as ≈øhe plea≈øes.
A Service of Gold, viz. Di≈øhes, Plates, Ba≈øons, and all manner of Uten≈øills both for the Table and the Cup-board.
A Trunck full of Gloves, Fanns, Silk-≈øtockings, Garters wrought with Gold, night and morning Garments.
All ≈øorts of E≈ø≈øences, Pomatums, and Perfumes, the mo≈øt exqui≈øite in Europe.

Two Calleches or Charetts, embroidered with Gold and Silver, the one Scarlet Velvet, drawn by ≈øix I≈øabel colour hor≈øes, come out of Mo≈øcovy; and the other of Green velvet, drawn by ≈øix hor≈øes of a very Extraordinary colour, drawing towards Incarnation, ≈øent by a Foreign Prince, not far from the Indias.
Mar≈øhal de Grammont pre≈øented her with a gold Fountain all ≈øet with Diamonds.
Never were finer Pre≈øents ≈øeen, nor ≈øo magnificent a Queen, and her Qualities and Conditions are ≈øuitable, being very Royal indeed.

div.head: Monday, June 11. at the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: It was re≈øolved, That Dr. Reynolds be de≈øired to carry on the work of Thank≈øgiving before this Hou≈øe on Thur≈øday come fortnight, the 28. of this in≈øtant Iune, (being a day ≈øet apart to return thanks to the Lord for his Maje≈øties ≈øafe return to his government and people) at S. Margaret; VVe≈øtmin≈øter.

Re≈øolved, That the Lord General take care that the Oath of Supremacy and Allegiance be admini≈øtred to all the Officers and Soldiers of the Army. That the Lord High Admiral of England do take care that it be admini≈øtred to the Commanders and Mariners of the Fleet.
That his Maje≈øty be de≈øired to i≈ø≈øue forth a Proclamation, requiring all to take the Oath of Supremacy and Allegiance, that are enjoined by Law ≈øo to do.
The Hou≈øe rea≈ø≈øumed the debate of the Bill of Indempnity and Oblivion, and read the Letter of Robert VVallop E≈øquire; as al≈øo the humble Petition of Charls Lord St. Iohn.

Re≈øolved, That Robert VVallop be di≈øcharged from being a Member of this Hou≈øe, and uncapable of bearing any office of publick tru≈øt in the Nation; and that he be committed into the cu≈øtody of the Sergeant at Arms attending the Hou≈øe.
Re≈øolved, That Luke Robin≈øon E≈øq be di≈øcharged from being a Member of this Hou≈øe.

Re≈øolved, That Sir Henry Vane be one of the Twenty to be excepted out of the General Act of Indempnity and Oblivion, to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, penalties and forfeitures (not extending to life) as ≈øhall be thought fit to be inflicted by an Act hereafter to be made for that purpo≈øe.
Re≈øolved, That VVilliam Lenthal E≈øq be one of the Twenty to be excepted out of the General Act of Indempnity and Oblivion, &c.
The Hou≈øe ordered new Writs to i≈ø≈øue for the election of Burge≈ø≈øes for the re≈øpective places following, viz.
A new Writ to i≈ø≈øue forth for the election of a Burge≈øs for Yiverton in com. Devon. Mr. Bampfield having waved the election thereof, to ≈øerve for Exeter.
A new Writ for a Burge≈øs to ≈øerve for VVhitchurch in com. Southton, in the place of Robert Wallop E≈øq di≈øcharged from being a Member of this Hou≈øe.
Another for Nottingham town, in the place of Col. Iohn Hutchin≈øon di≈øcharg it.
Another for North-Allerton, in the place of Francis La≈ø≈øels di≈øcharged.
Re≈øolved, That the Bill for Sales be taken into con≈øideration on Friday next.
Re≈øolved, That the Bill for Mini≈øters be taken into con≈øideration on Saturday next.
The Bill for Poll-money was read the fir≈øt time.
The petition of ≈øeveral in ≈ølavery under the Turk, was read and referred to a Committee.

Re≈øolved, That the ≈øad condition of the Lord Inchequin and his Son now Captives under the Turk, be repre≈øented to his Maje≈øty, and that his Maje≈øty be de≈øired that ≈øome effectual cour≈øe be taken for their redemption.

The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the debate upon the Bill of Indempnity and Oblivion, and ord ‚Ä¢ re ‚Ä¢ that William Burton be one of the Twenty to be excepted, and to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, p ‚Ä¢ nalties and forfeitures (not extending to life) as ≈øhall be thought fit to be inflicted on him by an Act hereafter to be made for that purpo≈øe.
A Petition of Mrs. Love was read.

div.head: Wedne≈øday, June 13. at the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: Letters Patents from His mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty; con≈øtituting Sir Orlando Bridgman Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer, Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Lords in the ab≈øence of the Lord Chancellor, were read and agreed unto whereupon the Lord Chancellor going away, Sir Orlando performed that office.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p:
The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the Debate concerning the Bill of Indempnity and Oblivion, and Ordered that
Oliver St. John
Colonel Sydenham
Alderman Ireton
Colonel Disbrow
Sir Arthur He≈øibrigge
be of the Twenty to be excepted &c.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: Sir William Salkeld was lately ≈øworne of the Gentlemen of the King; Privy chamber in ordinary. And be≈øides the≈øe formerly mentioned, the Marquis of Hertford and General Montague received the honor of the mo≈øt Noble Order of the Garter.

The Lords ≈øent a me≈ø≈øage to the Commons, de≈øiring their concurrence to a Petition to be pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty from both ‚Ä¢ ou≈øes, for publi≈øhing His Maje≈øties late Proclamation again≈øt debauched and prophane per≈øons, throughout the Kingdom, which the Commons agree unto.

Mr. Speaker informing the Hou≈øe, that Mr Meyne, Col. Waite, and Col. Temple, three of His late Maje≈øties Judges, had rendred them≈øelves to him according to the Proclamation, and that he had committed them to the Serjeant at Arms, the Hou≈øe approved of their commitment.

div.head: Whitehal June 11.
div.p: The Bayliffs, Burge≈ø≈øes, and commonalty of the Town of Ip≈øwich, upon the ≈øixth of this in≈øtant, as a Te≈øtimony of their Loyalty and good affection, after a Speech delivered by Mr. Nathaniel Bacon their Recorder, pre≈øented his Maje≈øty with Six hundred pound in Gold, by Mr Emanuel Sorrel, one of their Bayliffs, accompanied by Mr. Francis Bacon, Mr. John Sickbemore, Captain Robert Sparrow, Mr. Fi≈øher, Mr. Robert Clark, Lieutenant Thomas Wright, Mr. Henry Co≈øens, and Mr. Benjamin Brunning Lecturer of the ≈øaid Town, As a token of his Maje≈øties gracious acceptance, he was plea≈øed this day, to confer the Honor of Knighthood, upon Mr. Emanuel S ‚Ä¢ rrel.

div.head:
From Presburgh,
May 13, 1660.
div.p: The Turks having ≈øpoiled all the frontier of Hungary, are come further into the Country, which hath ≈øo alarumed the Inhabitants, that every one is fled, and even ≈øome ≈ømall Towns are totally de≈øerted, the people having found no better expedient to avoid the cruelty of tho≈øe Barbarians, ≈øet all a fire, and burn what≈øoever they cannot carry away; yet the Ba≈øhaw of Offen, who commands them, doth ≈øtill profe≈øs to be unwilling to undertake any thing again≈øt the Emperours Dominions, which is conceived to be out of policy, for fear of be ‚Ä¢ ng obliged to ingage with the Imperial Forces, before he receiveth the ≈øupply he is expecting „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ fir≈øt Vi≈øier, which be ‚Ä¢ ng once arrived, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ will be known, which in „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ he will pe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wade us to be only „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .

The Swedi≈øh forces formerly at Mariemburgh are removed, and are now quartered at Nogat, from whence they will not go, until all their arrears be paid them. Tho≈øe that were at ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bing begin al≈øo to mutiny; threatning to plunder the Inhab ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nts, unle≈øs they be ≈øpeedily ≈øatisfied. This hath obliged Major Generall Linden to go to Saphor, to acquaint the Swedi≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners with it, but they could nor rai≈øe yet the 20000 Crowns, though they have offered to give in pawn the Artillery they have here. The ≈øaid Major General coming this way hath vi≈øited the Count of Koning≈øm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ k who is not to go from hence until the Duke and Duche≈øs of Curland be at liberty, which will be very ≈øpeedily. The affairs in Lithuania are ≈øtill in a very bad po≈øture, and there is a very little likelihood to have them ea≈øily ≈øetled again, if what we hear be true, that the Poli≈øh Army hath been totally routed by the
Mo≈øcovites, who are ≈øaid to have taken pri≈øoner General Czarnesky who commanded it, and that in con≈øequence of that victory, part of their forces had marched towards War≈øow, and the re≈øt towards Pru≈ø≈øia, the confirmation whereof is daily expected. In the mean time the people are very much alarumd at this news; it is reported that the Elector of Brandenburgh intends to have all his forces now in Hol≈øtein and Meckleburgh, to march this way.

The Swedes ≈øeeing the ob≈øtinacy of tho≈øe with whom they are treating, to ≈øhew their inclination to the peace, ≈øent word lately to the Dutch Amba≈ø≈øadors, that they were willing to quit their preten≈øions about the 400000 Crowns the King of Denmark was to pay unto them, and even to yeild the Bailiwick of Druntheim, which having obliged the Commi≈ø≈øioners to meet again, it is thought that all things will be very ≈øpeedily concluded; but the ten Swedi≈øh Men of War are kept ≈øtill by Vice Admiral Ruyter, who to hinder them to have communication one with the other, hath taken away all their ≈øhalops.

The conferences having been renewed between the Commi≈ø≈øioners of both ≈øides, the la≈øt project of the Mediators was propounded for a Treaty betwixt the two Crowns; but when all things were thought to be concluded, the Swedes declared they would not accept of it, but upon ≈øuch condition, that the places ≈øhould not be re≈øtored till ≈øix weeks after the ratification, and that the ten Men of War belonging to them ≈øhould be pre≈øently delivered to them again, without ≈øtaying for the ≈øaid ratification. They likevvi≈øe propounded ≈øome nevv difficulties concerning the Treaty of Ell ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g, but the Dutch Amba≈ø≈øadors
told them, that unle≈øs vvithin tvvo daies they vvould give their con≈øent to the la≈øt Treaty, vvith the explanations added thereunto, for the immediate re≈øtitution of the places after the ratification of the Treaty betvvixt the tvvo Crovvns, and the keeping of the ten Ships until all the differences vvere ended, the Vice-Admiral Ruyter had order after that time to u≈øe ho≈øtility again≈øt them, which Declaration hath ≈øo incen≈øed the Swedi≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners, that they refu≈øed to continue any further that negotiation. Yet after ≈øome conferences they had with the Lord Hannibal See≈øtede, they were ≈øo well appea≈øed, that few daies after mo≈øt of the differences vvere decided, ≈øo that it is hoped the Treaty vvill be ≈øpeedily ≈øub≈øcribed, being chiefly grounded upon that of Ro≈øchild, and the project made at the Hague.

The Elector of Brandenburgh being returned hither tvvo daies ≈øince, hath ≈øent his fir≈øt Gentleman of the hor≈øe to the King of England to complement him upon the occa≈øion of his happy re≈øtoration.

Upon the advice come lately to the ≈øhips that are at Saint Tropez, that a Turki≈øh brigandine had taken fevv daies before a bark of Genoa, laden vvith vvine and oyl, they ≈øent one of their ve≈ø≈øels to pur≈øue the Pycates, vvhom they fought vvith ≈øuch re≈øolution, that they forced them to abandon their prize, vvhich vvas brought back again, vvith about eleven Turks that vvere upon her.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENTS.
div.p: Arnaldo, or, the injur'd Lover. An excellent new Romance; written in Italian by the excellent pen of Girolamo Bru≈øoni, made Engli≈øh by T. S. Sold by The Dring, at the George in Fleet≈øtreet, near St. Dun≈øtant Church.

The accompli≈øh'd Courtier; con≈øi≈øting of in≈øtitutions and examples by which Courtiers and Officers of State may ≈øquare their tran≈øactions pru ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ntly, and in good order and method. By H. W. Gent. Sold by T. Dring, at the George in Fleetstreet, near St. Dun≈øtans Church.

An iron grey Nag, price about ≈øeven pound, age between five and ≈øix, having all his paces being newly dockt, lo≈øt at VVorce≈øter, June 6. If any per≈øon can bring certain intelligence of him, to Richard A≈øhbey in VVorce≈øter, or unto John Green, H ‚Ä¢ bberda≈øher on London-bridge, he ≈øhall have ten ≈øhillings for his pains.

div.head:
Hamborough,
Iune 5. 1660. S. N.
div.p: This day we received the joyful news of the peace between the two Northern Crowns, which was not only concluded the 27th of May, but al≈øo proclaimed that very day; pre≈øently upon which the King of Denmark ≈øent order to the Governour of Gue ‚Ä¢ ≈øtad for the publi≈øhing of it, and for a ce≈ø≈øation of all kind of ho≈øtility. The Imperial and Brandenburghi≈øh forces in Hol≈øtein have al≈øo publi≈øhed the peace lately concluded between them and the Crown of Sweden, but it is not yet known when they will withdraw from thence; it is thought they will ≈øtay there until the ratification of the Treaty „Äà‚óä„Äâ in Pru≈ø≈øia be received.

div.head: An extract out of Letters from Zealand, concerning the Peace and the Articles there agreed on, dated the 28 ‚Ä¢ h of May, 1660.
div.p: YE≈øterday at eight of the clock at night, the articles of peace were ≈øub≈øcribed by the Danes, Swedes, and the Lord Mediators the French, Engli≈øh, and Hollanders, in the Tents ≈øet up for that purpo≈øe betwixt the Leaguer and Copenhagen, after which, ≈øo ≈øoon as our Rix Senators with the Lord Mediators were come into the Town, all the Guns upon the walls round about the Town, as al≈øo upon the Hollands Fleet, were three ‚Ä¢ imes di≈øcharged, be≈øides there were three volleys of Musket ≈øhot given by the Citizens and Souldiers; whereupon the Swedes in their leaguer gave likewi≈øe three volleys of ≈øhot out of their Canons; this la≈øted till ten of the clock in the night, and then the peace was proclaimed by the Kings Herald, by ≈øound of Trumpets and Kettle-drums through the whole Town.

div.head: A brief extract out of the Articles of Peace.
div.p: Six weeks after the date hereof, the whole Swedi≈øh Army is to quit Denmark, namely a fortnight after the ratification of the peace which is to be delivered in El≈øenore within four weeks.
1 The leaguer is to be evacuated four daies after the date above-mentioned.
2 Four daies after this Nicoping, Fal≈øter, and Moen are to be quitted, and the ≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ day Tonningen, Hu≈øum, and Eyder≈øtad in Hol≈øtein to be freed of all Dani≈øh forces.
3 Eight daies after this Na≈øcow in Laland.
4 And eight daies after Kocke in Zealand.
5 A fortnight after the ratification Cor≈øor and Crone ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rgh are to be quitted, and at the ≈øame time the Duke of Hol≈øtein his Territories is to be freed of the Dani≈øh forces.
His Maje≈øty will u≈øe his be≈øt endeavours by the allied Armies, that they likewi≈øe quit the Duke of Hol≈øtein his Territories at the limitted time.
Art. 3. The Swedi≈øh ≈øhips ≈øhall freely pa≈øs thorough the Sound without being vi≈øited or paying any cu≈øtomes.

Art. 6. The King of Denmark is to give yearly towards the keeping of the fire-beacons behind He ‚Ä¢ ≈øingo ‚Ä¢ 3 ‚Ä¢ 0 Rixdolors, and this to be paid at two ≈øeveral terms to the Swedi≈øh Mini≈øter re≈øiding at Hel≈øingor, which done, Sweden is to maintain the fire, without any pretence to the cu≈øtomes in the Sound.
Art. 10. The ≈øalt which remaineth yet due, and not ≈øatisfied, found aboard the three ≈øhips formerly ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ en, is to be paid at Han-borough within a year.
Art. 13. The Nobility in Schon ‚Ä¢ n are to have pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all their lands and moveables, and to take the oath of fidelity to Sweden.
Art. 16. The King of Denmark ≈øhall be free from giving any ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ sfaction for the for ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ying of Koege and Co ‚Ä¢ ≈øor.
Art. 17. The D ‚Ä¢ ke o ‚Ä¢ Hol≈øtein, according to the treaty of Copenhagen, is to keep the Juri≈ødiction of S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ b≈øtad, and half part of the Chapter of Sle≈øwig, and the Soveraignty.
Art. 28. Gottorf is „Äà‚óä„Äâ evacuated after the Dani≈øh places in Zealand are quitted.
Art. 29. The letter of renouncing Drontheim is to be brought in upon the delivery of the letters of ratification of the peace, and the Crown of Denmark is to enjoy Drontheim in perpetuum.
Art. 30. France, England, and Holland, take the Guaranty upon them to ≈øee all this performed.
Art. 31. The Crown of Swedeland is to po≈ø≈øe≈øs the I≈øle of Ween in perpetuum, and the Queen of Denmark to have the revenues thereof during her life.
Art. 32. Bornholm is to remain in the Danes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion for a year, and then to give an equivalent for it to the Swedes.
In all the other Articles, the Rotskilds peace is to remain in its full vigor.

div.head: Thur≈øday, Iune 14 at the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: The Hou≈øe this day read ≈øeveral private Petitions, and referred them to a Committee: They had likewi≈øe under their con≈øideration ≈øeveral things belonging to his Maje≈øties Revenue.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: The Petitions of Bul≈øtrode Whitlock, and Sir Robert Reynolds, were this day read.
The whole Election for the Borough of Wilton in the County of Wilts, upon report made, was voted void, and new Writs were thereupon ordered to be i≈ø≈øued forth for a new Election there.

Re≈ø. That Daniel Axtell be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the general Act of Indempnity and Obli ‚Ä¢ io ‚Ä¢ , to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, penalties, and forfeitures, not extending to life, as ≈øhall be inflicted on him by an Act hereafter to be made for that purpo≈øe.

div.head: Friday 15: At the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: This day the Lord Purbeck, by virtue of an Order of this Hou≈øe, was taken into the cu≈øtody of the Black Rod.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: The Hou≈øe ordered two Bills to be brought in for the continuing of the Cu≈øtomes and Exci≈øe for ≈øix moneths longer, to commence from Mid≈øummer next.

The Hou≈øe upon a former information of certain words pretended to be ≈øpoken by Col. White, in relation to the death of his late Maje≈øty of ble≈ø≈øed memory, referred the ≈øame to be examined by a Committee, and the examinations being this day reported,
It was re≈øolved, that the ≈øaid Col. White was not in the lea≈øt guilty of ≈øpeaking any ≈øuch words as were laid to his charge.

Mr. Speaker acquainted the Hou≈øe that Alderman Pennington, one of his late Maje≈øties Tryers, had rendred him≈øelf to him according to his Maje≈øties Proclamation, and that he had put him into the cu≈øtody of the Serjeant at Arms, till the plea≈øure of the Hou≈øe was further known; whereupon the Hou ‚Ä¢ e approved of it, and ordered him ≈øtill to remain in cu≈øtody.
The Que≈øtion being put whether Major General Butler ≈øhould be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the Act of Indempnity and Oblivioe, &c. it was carried in the negative.

Re≈øolved, that Iohn Blackwell, late Trea≈øurer of War, be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the general Act of pardon and Oblivion, to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, penalties, and forfeitures, not extending to life, as ≈øhall be inflicted on him by an Act hereafter to be made to that purpo≈øe.

div.head: Saturday 16. At the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: The Lord Purbeck was this day brought to the Bar of the Hou≈øe by the Black Rod, who hath him ≈øtill in cu≈øtody.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: Re≈øolved, That his Maje≈øty be humbly moved to call in Milion's two books, and Iohn Goodwins, and order them to be burnt by the common hangman.
That the Attorney General do proceed again≈øt them by Indictment, or otherwi≈øe.

Mr. Speaker informed the Hou≈øe that Alderman Tichbourn, Colonel George Fleetwood, and Colonel Temple, three of the Judges of his late Maje≈øty, had rendred them≈øelves to him, and that he had put them into the cu≈øtody of the Serjeant at arms, till the plea≈øure of the Hou≈øe was further known, whereupon the Hou≈øe approved of their commitment, and ordered them ≈øtill to remain in cu≈øtody.
The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the debate of the Act of Indempnity and Oblivion, and read the Petition of Frances, wife of Iohn Lambers, whereupon they ordered, &c.

That Colonel Iohn Lambers be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the general Act of Pardon and Oblivion, to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pain:, penalties, and forfeitures, not extending to life, as ≈øhall be inflicted on him by an Act hereafter to be made to that purpo≈øe.

The Que≈øtion being put, whether Alderman Chri≈øtopher Pack ≈øhould be of the twenty to be excepted, &c. It was ordered, That Alderman Chri≈øtopher Pack be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the general Act of Pardon.
The like O ‚Ä¢ der was made concerning Serjeant Ri. Keeble, that he be one of the twenty, &c.

His Maje≈øty ≈øet forth a Proclamation for recalling all Commi≈ø≈øions at Sea granted out by his Maje≈øty, or his Royal Brother, the Duke of York, before the fir≈øt of May la≈øt, willing and commanding every of them to forb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r further execution of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øione, upon pain of ≈øuch puni≈øhments as may legally be inflicted on pyrates; and likewi≈øe requiring all his Subjects imployed
in Sea affairs by any forreign Prince, to repair home to his Maje≈øties ≈øervice.

The ≈øame day the heads of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, with ≈øeveral Doctors in Scarlet, and many Ma≈øters of Att, were conducted by the Earl of Southampton (who by rea≈øon of the indi≈øpo≈øition of health of the Marque≈øs of Hertford their Chancellor, did that civility for them) and the Burge≈ø≈øes ≈øerving in Parliament for the Univer≈øity to his Maje≈øty, where Doctor Conaught the Vice-Chancellor made a ≈øpeech to his Maje≈øty, after which they had all the honor to ki≈øs his Maje≈øties hand.

This day al≈øo the Town of King≈øton upon Hull, who as they have not yeilded to any in expre≈ø≈øing and ≈øolemniz ‚Ä¢ ng among them≈øelves in the be≈øt manner their joy upon the ≈øeveral occa≈øions of the happy Return, and the proclaiming of his Maje≈øty, ≈øo for a further demon≈øtration of their loyalty, duty, and affection to his Maje≈øty, did this day by the hand of their Members in Parliament, and ≈øome others, per≈øons of Quality in that place, who had the honor to be introduced by his Excellency, pre≈øent to his Maje≈øty their humble addre≈øs, in congratulation of that gracious providence by which his Maje≈øty hath been re≈øtored to his people; and therewith they ‚Ä¢ endered al≈øo under the Seal of their Corporation, a Relea≈øe of certain Fee-farms there, which being in the≈øe times expo≈øed to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢ hey had redeemed out of other hands for twelve hundred pounds, and now joyfully re≈øtored them to his Maje≈øty, both which were by his Maje≈øty gratiou≈øly received, and with particular expre≈ø≈øions of favour to the ≈øaid Town.

On Saturday the 16. his ≈øacred Maje≈øty accompanied by his two Royal Brothers, the Duke of York, and Duke of Gloce≈øter, as al≈øo ≈øeveral of the N ‚Ä¢ bility and Gentry was plea≈øed to ≈øup with the Lord Mayor of London at his hou≈øe. Before ≈øupper the Lord Mayor brought to his Maje≈øty a napkin dipt in Ro≈øe-water, and off ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed it kneeling, with which when his Maje≈øty had wip'd his hands, he ≈øat down at a Table „Äà‚óä„Äâ by an a≈øcent, the Duke of York on his right hand, and the Duke of Gloce≈øter on his left; they were ≈øerved with three ≈øeveral cour≈øes, at each cour≈øe the Table-cloth was ≈øhifted, and at every di≈øh which his Maje≈øty, or the Dukes ta≈øted, the napkin. A ‚Ä¢ another table in the ≈øame room ≈øat bare „Äà‚óä„Äâ Excellency the Lord G ‚Ä¢ nera, the Duke of Buckingham, the Marque≈øs of Ormond, the Earl of Oxford, Earl of Norwich‚ñ™ Earl of Saint Albans Lord De la VVare, Lord San ‚Ä¢ s, Lord Bercley, and ≈øeveral other of the Nobility, with Knights and Gent ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n of great quality Sir John Robin≈ø ‚Ä¢ n, A „Äà‚óä„Äâ of London began in health to his Maje≈øty, which was pledged by „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Table ≈øtanding. His Maje≈øty was all the while entertained with variety of mu≈øick, and one that repre≈øented a Country man, with whom his Maje≈øty ≈øeemed to be w ‚Ä¢ ll plea≈øed. His Maje≈øty con ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ red the honor of Knighthood on Alderman John Lawrence, and Mr.
‚Ä¢ utler, two loyal Citizens, the two fir≈øt that his Maje≈øty be≈øtowed th ‚Ä¢ honour on in the City of London; on the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , as a memorial of his particular favour, he was plea≈øed to be≈øtow his own Sword.
